page.title: 05Carn Brea
page.content: Carn Brea is between Camborne and Redruth.It is a hill,and the name Carn Brea is Cornish for 'rocky hill'.It has two historical sites,the castle and the monument. The earliest record of the castle is when it was used as a chapel in 1379.The present building is much larger than the original foundations and the last extension was the South wing built in 1979.It is now used as a restaurant. The monument is a giant cross South West of the castle.The foundation stone was laid in June 1836.It was erected in honour of Francis Lord de Dunstanville who was described as "a great and good man,Nobleman,Patriot and a Christian,Philanthropist and adviser of the poor." The Carn is interesting to explore and well worth a visit if you are on holiday.
